<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 123, 645, 149]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 222, 170, 252]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 214, 428, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[621, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 214, 907, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 235, 293]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 278, 907, 293]]<|/det|>
9709/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 243, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 907, 319]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 880, 648]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 216, 695]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 696, 732, 728]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(P\) and \(Q\), of masses \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.5 \mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are at rest on a smooth horizontal plane. \(P\) is projected towards \(Q\) with speed \(2 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 423, 139]]<|/det|>
Write down the momentum of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 301, 146, 319]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 300, 816, 319]]<|/det|>
After the collision \(P\) continues to move in the same direction with speed \(0.3 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 331, 468, 350]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of \(Q\) after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 332, 920, 350]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 82, 725, 240]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 260, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
A block of mass \(m \mathrm{~kg}\) is held in equilibrium below a horizontal ceiling by two strings, as shown in the diagram. One of the strings is inclined at \(45^{\circ}\) to the horizontal and the tension in this string is \(T \mathrm{~N}\). The other string is inclined at \(60^{\circ}\) to the horizontal and the tension in this string is \(20 \mathrm{~N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 324, 235, 342]]<|/det|>
Find \(T\) and \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 324, 920, 342]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 84, 811, 295]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 313, 920, 396]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a velocity-time graph which models the motion of a car. The graph consists of four straight line segments. The car accelerates at a constant rate of \(2 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 2}\) from rest to a speed of \(20 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) over a period of \(T \mathrm{~s}\). It then decelerates at a constant rate for 5 seconds before travelling at a constant speed of \(V \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) for \(27.5 \mathrm{~s}\). The car then decelerates to rest at a constant rate over a period of \(5 \mathrm{~s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 409, 146, 427]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 409, 222, 427]]<|/det|>
Find \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 410, 918, 427]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Given that the distance travelled up to the point at which the car begins to move with constant speed is one third of the total distance travelled, find \(V\). [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 888, 92]]<|/det|>
A particle is projected vertically upwards with speed \(40 \text{m s}^{-1}\) alongside a building of height \(h \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 794, 123]]<|/det|>
Given that the particle is above the level of the top of the building for 4 s, find \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
One second after the first particle is projected, a second particle is projected vertically upwards from the top of the building with speed \(20 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
Denoting the time after projection of the first particle by \(t\) s, find the value of \(t\) for which the two particles are at the same height above the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A block of mass \(5\mathrm{kg}\) is placed on a plane inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The coefficient of friction between the block and the plane is \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 129, 710, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[531, 297, 596, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 333, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
When a force of magnitude \(40 \mathrm{~N}\) is applied to the block, acting up the plane parallel to a line of greatest slope, the block begins to slide up the plane (see Fig. 6.1).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 380, 314, 400]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mu < \frac{1}{5}\sqrt{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 382, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 87, 715, 233]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[536, 250, 603, 268]]<|/det|>
<mark>[b]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 288, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
When a force of magnitude \(40 \mathrm{~N}\) is applied horizontally, in a vertical plane containing a line of greatest slope, the block does not move (see Fig. 6.2).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 336, 767, 355]]<|/det|>
Show that, correct to 3 decimal places, the least possible value of \(\mu\) is 0.152.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 337, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) moves in a straight line, starting from a point \(O\) with velocity \(1.72 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\). The acceleration \(a \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}\) of the particle, \(t \mathrm{~s}\) after leaving \(O\), is given by \(a = 0.1t^{\frac{3}{2}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 125, 146, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 125, 576, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(t\) when the velocity of \(P\) is \(3 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 126, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 915, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the displacement of \(P\) from \(O\) when \(t = 2\), giving your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 88, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 87, 816, 222]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 238, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(A\) and \(B\), of masses \(0.3 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.5 \mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a fixed smooth pulley which is attached to a horizontal plane and to the top of an inclined plane. The particles are initially at rest with \(A\) on the horizontal plane and \(B\) on the inclined plane, which makes an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) with the horizontal. The string is taut and \(B\) can move on a line of greatest slope of the inclined plane. A force of magnitude \(3.5 \mathrm{N}\) is applied to \(B\) acting down the plane (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 348, 148, 366]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 348, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
Given that both planes are smooth, find the tension in the string and the acceleration of \(B\). [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 384, 917, 401]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 940, 175, 955]]<|/det|>
<label>©</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that the two planes are rough. When each particle has moved a distance of \(0.6 \text{m}\) from rest, the total amount of work done against friction is \(1.1 \text{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
Use an energy method to find the speed of \(B\) when it has moved this distance down the plane. [You should assume that the string is sufficiently long so that \(A\) does not hit the pulley when it moves \(0.6 \text{m}\).]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
